title: Modelling decimalisation in the Nasdaq stockmarket
segmentation: Thank you.
Do wave at the back if I'm not not audible.
Let's wait for the last few to come in.
So I'm going to take you through some work which was not exclusively machine learning base, but had a significant machine learning element that was done.
This work was actually done about nine years ago.
Now Anne was looking at modeling what the impact of decimalisation would be in the NASDAQ stock market.
I'll take you through what that what that means for those of you who are not not familiar with it.
It was a collaborative effort with quite a large group of people.
And this is actually a piece of basically paid consulting work sponsored by the Board of NASDAQ.

In particular Mike Brown and Al Berkeley, and so from that point of view is perhaps a bit different from your standard bit of research, and I'll come later to some of the implications of that and complications.
That so the basic problem was that the.

The SEC was pushing an agenda of decimal Ising the markets and what that means is in the old days markets in America world quoted Alstott minimum tick increment was a 16th or an eighth of a dollar on most stocks, so it's the minimum price change and the aim was to decimalize the markets and turn that into a penny.
And that's the way the markets operate today.
And there were questions at the time as to what the impact of that might be on the markets, and you know, perhaps one might think there should be no effect at all.
But it's it.
The obvious difference.
Well, the only difference really is that this minimum price change of any stock will change from being typically about 6 cents to being 1 cent.

So there's a sort of a fine grained, very large difference, and the question is does actually have any significant macroscopic effects of any kind, and that's what we set out to model, and the key concerns the reason this was quite an important issue.
Was that many, many policy changes in the past that the NASDAQ had been through.

They'd experienced after the fact that the participants in the market day traders, market makers, pension funds and so on changed their behavior in significant ways and in unexpected ways, and that in many many cases this led to.

Two negative consequences on the market an let them would then lead them to make yet further changes in an effort to compensate for these things that hadn't been predicted beforehand, and so the aim was really to understand whether decimal Ising the markets would lead to changes in the participants behavior in their strategies, and if So what the implications of that might be on things like volatility.
Efficiency of price discovery.
The fairness of the market.
All these sorts of well defined and ill defined things at the markets trying to achieve.
So that's what we set out to do.
And.
The.
It's obviously quite a difficult thing to do, particularly to sort of validate such predictions and validate the fairly complex model of the markets and so.

They were so the number of different approaches taken to do this, some of them very very much data driven, some of them much more sort of modeling and experimental and sort of hands-on, and the machine learning approaches within that were quite important in trying to ascertain that what was being done didn't leave sort of loopholes by which strategies could be learned that would significantly change the dynamics of the market.
And.
Clearly a very important part of any of this.
So we built a simulation of a significant portion of the NASDAQ stock market.
Very important part of this was to validate and demonstrate that the simulation was sufficiently.

Sufficiently similar to the market at that time, and sufficiently robust that when we started to manipulate the market, in other words, introduced decimalisation or other policy changes that there could be some degree of confidence in the outcomes.
And that's sort of sufficiently similar.

Thing is not something that we could sort of rigorously define, basically involved some numerical work for sure, but also a lot of expert market participants are various kalkines, including the regulators trying to understand what this model was doing and and critiquing it.
So this is the basic sort of flow of logic in our approach to the problem.

Rule changes will impact the kinds of decisions and the and the data that is available to three different main categories of individual in the market as individual investors, market makers and professional traders.
For those of you who are not familiar with the way in which the NASDAQ market operates in a moment, I'll explain to you what the market makers are and how they behave so.
We can come to that in a moment.
Then that market is in fact not entirely one market.
'cause there's there's various electronic trading networks that sort of operate sort of.
His part of it, and sort of separately, and so there's some complications there.
And all of these things come together to produce the dynamics that we observe.
And this is the area where we can actually measure things and and look at the numbers.
We were also, I guess, as part of this because this was work sponsored by the NASDAQ.
We were able to get.

Many years worth of historical textreme data, including the actual identifiers of the market makers and so on who are concerned with in it, and that actually allowed us to do a level of validation at this level.
Here, the level of actual individual behaviors of some of these market makers, so given stock will have somewhere between 10 and 20 market makers competing to set the bid and the ask.
And so we could actually do to a certain extent, quite detailed validation against their behaviors, because we had this sort of internal data source that's obviously highly confidential.
Anne.
So here's a quick summary of what we did, so we built this simulation based model of the market with agents representing the different market participants.
We simulated the market infrastructure, the ways in which these different participants communicate and the way in which the prices are formed.
We calibrated many of those behaviors with this real data.
We also used variety of machine learning models to try to evolve or learn strategies which would be profitable within this market.
And and try to ensure that the simulated distribution of all these sorts of measures was similar to reality and.
Anne.
Well, I'll come to what that what the results of that were in a moment.
But that was we were able to do that fairly fairly well.

And then one further sort of set of validation was we actually built into this, a sort of front end into the simulation, very similar to the front ends that market makers were using at the time, which allowed allowed some of the actual market makers to participate within this simulation and give it an additional sort of.
Sort of intuitive feel as to whether it was something that was similar to the environment they faced every day or not, and that was another thing that allowed us to do certain amount of fine tuning.
How?
So here's a few sort of.
Observations of.
Of some of the thoughts that we had at the time and afterwards of weather, of whether this was going to be a successful project.
What kinds of models we should be considering, and what kinds of predictions we might be able to make.
And I guess some of the key reasons that we built the model in this particular way.
We're sort of listed here, but the fact that the market is very very heterogeneous, there's very broad range of different strategies.

At that particular time with thesortof.com boom and all that sort of thing, day trading was a major force and there was a feeling that modeling those kinds of strategies as distinct from others would be very important for understanding the outcomes.
And really, being able to look at many different scenarios and try and understand what kinds of strategies would be profitable under different kinds of scenarios was very important.
And really, a lot of that was driven back to again, some of Nasdaq's historical historical problems they observed with some of the previous policy changes that they made.
And I said a number of these.
I don't really want to go into now.
Just to be clear, there was a study carried out internally at NASDAQ to try and try to forecast the impact of decimalisation.

It was a very, very thorough study, but as with as with previous such studies done at NASDAQ, the There's a long list of caveats there, and the caveats kind of cover all of the problems that NASDAQ have seen in the past and basically evolve around around market participants changing their strategies as a result of changes to the market.
So this study this study, as with previous ones, was very much historical, data driven.
And and in almost every event after the fact, analysis has shown that the market participants do change their strategies and that that sort of invalidates the data driven approach there.
So it's just sort of an inevitable problem that we were trying to work around.
So let me just run through.
Two different agents, so market makers, as I mentioned a moment ago in the NASDAQ market, there is between 10 and 20.
Typically market makers competing in each in each stock to set the bid and the ask.
And.
So that's very distinct from the New York Stock Exchange, where there's a single specialist carrying out that role.
In addition, the ecn's electronic communication networks that sort of sit around NASDAQ Island archipelago is a few different ones.
They also, in many ways, Act as a kind of proxy market maker, so it's very important for us to be able to model these things very, very precisely.
And using the sort of historical data we had access to, we're able to very good job of modeling their behavior very precisely.
And I'll come in a moment to one of the things that we observed when looking at some of that data.

So there was one historical situation that NASDAQ had, which was in some sense similar to this which was the move a few years before from many of the stocks being quoted in eighths to moving to sixteenths.
And so we spent a fair amount of time looking at that transition, and.
Observe some sort of interesting things.
There's obviously lots of different types of investors in the market.
And it was important to model those those sort of broad range of different kinds there.
Interestingly enough, when we began doing the machine learning part of this to try and learn trading strategies within this simulated marketplace, that would be successful.
Actually got quite a lot of feedback from people in the markets that we shouldn't focus only on strategies that actually make money, and that strategies that don't make money should also be included.

And the strong the Silvius example of that was that was the day trading community where there's just A at that stage was just have an endless supply of day traders coming to the market, most of whom would lose their money.
And so that sort of made made it a bit more.
Another sort of complicated twist.
What we were doing.
And Fortunately was sort of certain amount of data we could go on there, but it just shows there's there's there's always complications.
We, in terms of the strategies, they were sort of three main kinds.
There were some sort of handcrafted strategies where we spent quite a lot of time sitting down with day traders and market makers observing what they did, talking to them about what they did.
And and trying to extract sort of rules of thumb.
Particular market making point of view when 95% of what they do is extremely sort of routine.
We see there you know their skill is in the other 5%, but in terms of setting a kind of baseline set of behaviors in the models, it was very helpful to be able to get these sorts of rules of thumbs.
Rules of thumb from the market makers about how they adjusted their quotes based upon the sort of information and the flow of trades that they observed.
We see a large machine learning element and a variety of other evolutionary techniques that we used which were mostly of lesser success.
I would have to say on the other evolutionary areas.
Various levels of sophistication and adaptability within these strategies, ranging as I said from very, very simple rules of thumb to some quite complex models and a lot of learning algorithms.
And.

Obviously other market participants are looking at many, many stocks, so there's certainly some assumptions there that that we had to make.
I guess one.
One interesting thing about the fact that it's a simulation is that we in some sense we were able to control the underlying sort of true value or whatever of the stock.

Looking at real world markets 'cause there isn't isn't.

The notion of a parasitic strategy, which was.

So kind of front running strategy and.
There's a we spent quite a lot of time modeling such strategies and trying to understand them.
And.
And in fact they turned out to be sort of in many ways.
If there was a single sort of crux of our whole piece of modeling, it really was.
I guess the understanding and the predictions around parasitic strategies.

Loosely Speaking of parasitic well, there are many different kinds of parasites strategies I should say, but a simple way to explain one of them is a strategy that when the market appears, excessively volatile sits back and doesn't really do very much.

So if we consider things from the point of view of a market maker for the moment, so market makers having to set this bid and ask and so parasitic approach, that would would when the market is excessively volatile would.
Provide extremely uncompetitive prices and therefore would see no action at all.
And then as the strategy decided, that the that the.

That the prices were beginning to settle down and were beginning to be meaningful, and therefore that the level of risk involved will be lower at that stage of parasitic strategy would would cut inside on one or other of the bid and the ask would undercut the current prices.
And therefore therefore most most normally a bunch of transactions would be executed against them.

And then when later on some sort of seconds later, when again very sort of trigger factors, that agent would decide that the the situation was becoming sort of unstable and would again for provide very uncompetitive quotes.
And there are many different kinds of such strategies.

But the interesting thing when we when we began sort of understanding about them and observing them in modeling them, was that they kind of pointed to a very obvious indirect reason why decimalisation might have a big impact on the markets, in that if you've got a strategy that basically involves undercutting other participants prices, if you're forced to undercut by a 16th of a dollar, that's both.
More risky and less frequently that you can do that.
And.
And there's less profit potentially to be made then.
If you can undercut by just a single penny.
So that was sort of the biggest was at that stage of this work, with sort of beginning to think that this might be important.
It turned out to be exactly right.

What we discovered more was that if you're trying to execute a small small trade for a small number of shares that actually as a result of the chain of decimalisation, you would likely get a better price for that transaction.

Then basically everything was a lot worse than the information that you had at anytime when looking at the market.
As to the price you might get was very poor, so you can.

You could easily see in the market what price you would be able to get for a small transaction, but the moment you try and execute a larger transaction, the amount by which the price would move on you was very very very very unpredictable.

Sometimes we move a lot and it was very, very difficult to determine the up front.
So that meant that there was an.
In general, the average price you'd end up getting was worse than before decimalisation.

System called the Super Montage was introduced, which allowed NASDAQ to actually provide more information to market participants about the depth of the depth on each side of the spread.

The best price that shown is what you might only be able to execute a few 100 share trading, but also looking at the depth behind that and you therefore get information about about what kind of price you're going to get in when you're going to execute trades involving thousands or sometimes 10s of thousands of shares.
